name: CIRCOS PanGenome
tagline: Calculates overlap of multiple genomes and prepares files for CIRCOS visualization software
body:
### Welcome to the PanGenome Creator

### The Prokaryotic Genome
The prokaryotic genome is one continuous strand of DNA, unlike ours, which is made of multiple chromosomes. Because it is circular, the prokaryotic genome is perfect for CIRCOS visualization software, which, for this program, shows the overlap of the genomes of many different species. 

### Genomic Comparision
One reason this is useful is for inter-species genomic comparision. If you have many similar species, it may be useful to pinpoint specific genes that are common to a group as well as isolate genes that are unique to a specific strand. In this way, you may be able to see how a specific gene contributes to that species' environment. 

To see how CIRCOS visualization nicely compliments our program, click [here](http://i.imgur.com/ufQLmbf.png).

### User Guide
On a Linux based system, you can call the program right into the command line. It has 2 required parameters, both of which are text files. The first describes your clusters of genes. The second is a text file with the names of your corresponding FASTA files on separate lines. Each fasta file must contain the name of your protein and the amino acid sequence in standard FASTA format.

The program can be called by:

`[user@localhost] $ python pangenome.py groups.txt fasta_files.txt`

After pangenome.py is run, you can generate your PanGenome via CIRCOS visualization:

`[user@localhost] $ circos -conf config_file.conf`

Simply update your .conf file with your files generated by pangenome.py.

### Authors 
This program was created by Evan Denmark (@edenmark) and Matthew Neave (@neavemj) at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Apprill Lab.
